awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Colorado/JILA. The site will support eight students per year for ten weeks of summer research. The intellectual focus of this REU program is physics, and undergraduate students are paired up with preeminent faculty to do cutting-edge research in many fields of physics, including atomic, molecular, and optical physics, biophysics, condensed matter physics, high energy physics, nuclear physics, plasma physics, quantum physics, quantum information science, and physics education research. 

While the main emphasis of the summer is centered on each student's individual research lab, where the students are expected to master at least a part of a large task, a variety of other activities take place during the program. These include ethics, electronics, and machining classes, a program on "Getting Into Grad School," as well as lab tours and a weekly science seminar series aimed at the students. The program culminates with a day of presentations given by each of the REU students. Special efforts are made to include significant participation levels from women and minorities, as well as from students coming from smaller institutions that do not have as many research opportunities. This program fits in with the NSF goal of developing a diverse and internationally competitive scientific and engineering workforce. Active research experience is one of the most effective ways to attract talented undergraduates and retain them in careers in science and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our program was titled "Research Experience for Undergraduates at Physics/JILA" and is centered at the University of Colorado, Boulder.  Our program website is:  http://www.colorado.edu/physics/Web/reu

This grant ran for four years and directly supported 30 students (~ 10 students per summer) to come to our campus for 10 week long intensive summer programs of research and education opportunities. Our program indirectly supported approximately 10 other summer students from associated programs who joined our programming, making for a larger and more active group each summer. COVID interrupted our program, so during the summer of 2020 we only had three students in the program and they performed their studies in a more contained environment.  Due to the almost total loss of that summer we requested a no-cost-extension to extend the program to a four-year term.  We ran a regular in-person program during the summer of 2021, which was one of the few REU programs to do so nationwide.

The students that we supported were highly diverse, with the vast majority either from an underrepresented minority or gender, as well as ~ half coming from small colleges where the students do not have much access to research opportunities.

The intellectual focus of this REU program is physics. Undergraduate students were paired up with preeminent faculty to do cutting-edge research in essentially all fields of physics. Fields that the students worked in included Atomic Molecular and Optical Physics, BioPhysics, Condensed Matter Physics, Renewable and Sustainable Energy, Geophysics, Nuclear Physics, Plasma Physics, Particle Physics, and Physics Education Research. We also had machine shop classes, data visualization classes, scientific writing workshops, panels with existing PhD students, discussions on 'getting into grad school', and a number of social activities. In the last week of the program each student gave a 15 minute presentation about their research. Each student also turned in a final paper describing their research project.  The students are trained as independent scientists and researchers, which is very different from the vast majority of the training that they get in a standard college curriculum.  This is a critical transition for most students, and is the main point of our program.

The broader impacts of this program are many.  It fits in with the NSF goal of developing a diverse and internationally competitive scientific and engineering workforce.  In general, active research experience is one of the most effective ways to attract talented undergraduates and retain them in careers in science and engineering. We did a variety of evaluations of the effectiveness of the program and the satisfaction of the students with the program. We found that the program was in general very well received and worthwhile.  We use this feedback to continue to improve our program.  We find that our students are better equipped to contribute to the rest of society. Not all of the students that we educate stay within physics or even within science.  However, the understanding that they gain about the scientific process, how research is performed, about ethics, and about communications skills will be beneficial to them and to their future colleagues, no matter what they end up doing.  A few students from our program have appeared as coauthors on published research papers.
